Microsoft Ignite is in San Francisco right now, bringing 20,000 people to our city and generating an estimated $68 million in economic impact and 68,000 hotel room nights. Today, Judson Althoff and I announced that this flagship tech conference is coming back to San Francisco in 2026!
¬†
By establishing San Francisco as their home,¬†Microsoft¬†is reaffirming what we already know: our city is a global hub of innovation. Ignite‚Äôs return adds to a strong year ahead for Moscone Center, which will host 36 major events in 2026‚Äîoutpacing 2025 and continuing the momentum we‚Äôre building across the city.

author: Unknown
post_text:
I was so pleased to be joined by customers and partners around the world for Microsoft Ignite with 20,000 attendees joining in San Francisco and 200,000 online. It is an exciting time as we shift from an era of AI Transformation to Frontier Transformation: a holistic reimagining of your business, aligning AI with human ambition to achieve your organization's highest aspirations and potential. By democratizing intelligence‚Äîempowered by Copilots and agents‚Äîwe will help them obsolesce the mundane, unlock creativity, and drive even greater innovation. 

As our customers realize success, we have identified three common themes below with new product announcements aimed at empowering the Frontier Firm:

1.¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†AI in the flow of human ambition. AI needs to be seamlessly accessible in the tools and solutions people use every day and tied to the key business metrics they use to determine ROI. Work IQ amplifies an individual‚Äôs IQ‚Äîit is the intelligence layer that enables Microsoft 365 Copilot and agents to know how you work, with whom you work, and the content you collaborate on. 

2.¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†Ubiquitous innovation. There is a maker in every one of us. The person closest to the challenge is often the best to solve it. Empowering employees with the ability to create AI artifacts in the flow of work and coupling citizen development with IT and professional developers through robust collaboration enables innovate at pace. 

‚ñ™Ô∏è Foundry IQ is the intelligent connection point between all structured and unstructured knowledge and models that agents need. It is the first large scale implementation of context engineering pulling from multiple sources through a single API.

‚ñ™Ô∏è Fabric IQ is the semantic layer that agents and apps use to reason with enterprise context across your entire data estate, turning unified data into unified intelligence for decisions. If you are already using Power BI, all pre-existing data modeling will act as an immediate accelerant, giving your agents the unique context that defines how your business runs.

‚ñ™Ô∏è Microsoft Agent Factory harnesses the power of Work IQ, Foundry IQ, and Fabric IQ through a single metered plan, measuring ROI for AI before you start building agents. You can leverage our forward-deployed engineers, our partners, and our skilling assets to build and deliver agents.

3.¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†Observability at every layer of the stack. You need to see all AI artifacts and how they are being used in real workflows. Microsoft Agent 365 enables you to observe, manage, and secure your AI agents whether they are created with Microsoft platforms, open-source frameworks, or third-party platforms.

Underpinning these three traits are the fundamental Frontier building blocks of Intelligence + Trust, enabled by Microsoft‚Äôs model diverse, open, and heterogenous platforms, we can bring together your organization‚Äôs IQ and help you achieve your highest aspirations in the pursuit of Frontier Transformation.

https://lnkd.in/gvUW-M8a

post_text:
It‚Äôs been an incredible start to #MSIgnite here in San Francisco! Yesterday during the keynote, we shared how Microsoft is evolving the AI stack to help organizations build agents that are intelligent, trustworthy, and deeply grounded in their business.
¬†
A big part of this evolution is giving agents the context, data, and oversight they need to operate effectively across the enterprise. We introduced Work IQ, which powers Microsoft 365 Copilot and agents with real-time signals from your files, meetings, messages, and work patterns. Plus, Fabric IQ and Foundry IQ to bring together operational and analytical data to give both agents and people a connected, live view of the business.
¬†
We also introduced Agent 365 ‚Äì a single place to manage and secure agents. I had a fantastic conversation with¬†Tao Zhang from Manus AI, Dean Arnold from Workday, and Paul Fipps from ServiceNow about observability and governance. One message is clear: the next phase of AI will be about scaling trust and visibility, to deliver real business impact.
¬†
And this is just the beginning of an exciting week at Ignite. It was great to join¬†Judson Althoff, Scott Guthrie, Asha Sharma, and Ryan Roslansky on stage to kick off such a pivotal moment for AI and the future of work.

author: Unknown
post_text:
Two *very*‚Äã big new things for Power Platform landing today:

1. üëã Introducing vibe.PowerApps.com ‚Äî full-stack app generation that's as easy to use as it is enterprise-grade, all new and ready to try now!

2. Apps + Agents = Awesome ‚ú®. M365 Copilot is coming to every app, and every agent is getting app skills with the new Power Apps MCP Server.

A lot‚Äã more detail and some great demos on the blog https://lnkd.in/ePfPfnEg as well as at this Ignite session where we'll tell the whole story cover to cover https://lnkd.in/emCXjEQW

In the meantime, here's what you need to know:

Vibe.PowerApps takes agent-first app development to the next level in a completely new experience. A whole team of agents work together with you to define requirements, data models, and solution architecture... and now the newest agent on the team will code a full-stack application from scratch in minutes. You can give the agents feedback in chat or point and click to get exactly what you want. All the traditional limitations of low code are gone now that an agent team is working for you; beautiful themes, custom styling, advanced interactions and delightful animation are just a few prompts away. It's ready today in public preview for anyone to try ‚Äî give it a shot!

What's more, apps on the platform are getting a massive agent upgrade. We're bringing the full Microsoft 365 Copilot experience directly into Power Apps, including powerful agents like Researcher and Analyst. This means users can now combine their app context with the rest of their "Work IQ" including emails, documents, messages, and more, and ask Copilot to do things like prepare research reports or presentations based on the context of their business data. 

At the same time, we're introducing a new Power Apps MCP Server so any agent can use key capabilities from apps ‚Äî including agent-centric app skills like intelligent data entry. And as agents do more work autonomously on their own or outside of apps, the upgraded Agent Feed makes it possible to quickly keep tabs across all of their activity.

All this is happening against the backdrop of some awesome advancements in the Managed Platform's ability to govern and host all the new AI-first workloads, as well as some great additions in Copilot Studio and the introduction of Agent 365.

There has never been a better time to get serious about modernizing the way your organization operates at scale. Let's go!

post_text:
Today, we‚Äôre introducing Agent 365 ‚Äì a new agent control plane to help every organization scale AI agents.
¬†
With Agent 365, you can manage and secure agents with the same rigor you apply to people, apps, and data. This spans 5 key things:
‚úÖ A unified registry to track every agent across your organization
‚úÖ Access control for built-in policy enforcement from day one
‚úÖ Visualization and insights to monitor usage, performance, and ROI
‚úÖ Interoperability across Microsoft, open-source, and partner ecosystems
‚úÖ Security with enterprise-grade compliance via Defender, Entra, and Purview
¬†
Agent 365 provides the foundation to run and secure all your agents in a single place - whether you‚Äôre building agents in Copilot Studio and Microsoft Foundry or using ones from partners across our growing ecosystem. 
¬†
This is how we move from experimentation to transformation as Frontier Firms and I can‚Äôt wait to share more about this at #MSIgnite this week!
¬†
You can check out the blog for all the details:

author: Unknown
post_text:
What if your browser could actually make your workday easier? Now it can. Today we're announcing Microsoft Edge is the first AI browser in the enterprise -¬†here's why it's about to make a huge difference in your workday:
¬†
Agent mode: You can finally delegate and get things off your plate - especially those tedious, time-consuming tasks. Edge for Business can take action on your behalf through multi-step workflows like booking travel for that conference or filling out forms. You'll provide input at key decision points and can take over at any time - but it'll take on the heavy lifting for you.
¬†
Daily Briefing: Cut through the fluff and see what you really need to tackle. Get a curated highlight of meetings, tasks, and priorities for your day, drawing on Microsoft Graph (like Teams and Outlook) and browser context.
¬†
Multi-tab reasoning: Stop flipping between tabs - and clicking the wrong one. Copilot can analyze content across up to 30 (!) open tabs, whether they‚Äôre web pages or internal sites, so you can synthesize several sources or compare different options. This has probably been the most loved update for consumer users, and we're thrilled to bring it to work too.
¬†
Search your history with natural language: For when you really need that one thing you read, and it's somewhere in hundreds of links you've visited. Just ask "what's that article I was reading about clean energy growth last week," and Copilot can find it.
¬†
YouTube summarization: No more sitting through an hour-long video for that one minute of information you need. Copilot can summarize the whole thing, or answer questions the content when you're looking for something specific.
¬†
It's all built on our enterprise foundation with world-class security in every layer of the browser stack, and opt-in for both IT teams and users.
¬†
Features are in private preview, with public previews coming in February across Windows, Mac, iOS and Android. I can't wait for you to feel the difference.

author: Unknown
post_text:
Today we announced our new Fairwater datacenter in Atlanta, connected with our first Fairwater site in Wisconsin and our broader Azure footprint to create the world‚Äôs first AI superfactory.

Fairwater exemplifies our vision for a fungible fleet: infra that can serve any workload, anywhere, on fit-for-purpose accelerators and network paths, with maximum performance and efficiency.

AI workloads have evolved beyond large-scale pre-training. Today, they encompass fine-tuning, reinforcement learning (RL), synthetic data generation, evaluation pipelines, and more. Fairwater is built to support this full lifecycle:

Max density: Fairwater‚Äôs two-story design and liquid cooling system lets us place racks in three dimensions and pack them with GPUs as densely as possible, minimizing cable runs and improving latency and effective bandwidth.

Fleet: Each Fairwater DC can integrate hundreds of thousands of the latest NVIDIA GPUs into a single coherent cluster. This provides flexible infra that can support the full spectrum of workloads, and ensure no GPU is left unnecessarily idle.

And that‚Äôs on top of the more than 100,000 GB300s coming online this quarter alone for inference across the rest of our fleet. For us, it‚Äôs all about turning every gigawatt into the maximum number of useful tokens. Not every GW is created equal!

Planet-scale: Every Fairwater DC will connect through our continent-spanning AI WAN to prior generations of AI supercomputers, forming a truly fungible pool of compute. This enables developers to scale beyond the capacity of a single site and dynamically land workloads on the right infra for their needs.

Together, these innovations let us bring together different generations of silicon and AI systems across DCs and geos into a single elastic system that scales seamlessly across training and inference workloads

And this elastic AI capacity is all available alongside all the other cloud services (compute, storage, databases, app services) that AI agents and workloads need.

This is what we mean when we talk about building a fungible fleet ‚Äì a single, unified platform that pushes the limits of performance per watt and per dollar.

Read more: https://lnkd.in/e82Dm2jQ

post_text:
On November 18-21 in San Francisco, we are hosting our largest customer and partner¬†event of the year: Microsoft Ignite. We will focus on what it means to become a Frontier firm‚Äîto empower human ambition and find AI-first differentiation in everything we do‚Äîand detail how we are demanding more from AI to solve humanity‚Äôs biggest challenges by democratizing intelligence, obsolescing the mundane, and unlocking creativity. author: Unknown
post_text:
Here‚Äôs a question that‚Äôs not getting the attention it deserves: what kind of AI does the world really want? I think it's probably the most important question of our time. For several years now, progress has been phenomenal. If AGI is often seen as the point at which an AI can match human performance at all tasks, then superintelligence is when it can go far beyond that performance.
¬†
Instead of endlessly debating capabilities or timing, it's time to think hard about the purpose of technology, what we want from it, what its limitations should be, and how we‚Äôre going to ensure this incredible tech always benefits humanity.
¬†
At Microsoft AI, we‚Äôre working towards Humanist Superintelligence (HSI): incredibly advanced AI capabilities that always work for, in service of, people and humanity more generally. We think of it as systems that are problem-oriented and tend towards the domain specific. Not an unbounded and unlimited entity with high degrees of autonomy ‚Äì but AI that is carefully calibrated, contextualized, within limits.
¬†
To do this we have formed the MAI Superintelligence Team, led by me as part of Microsoft AI. We want it to be the world‚Äôs best place to research and build AI, bar none. We are doing this to solve real concrete problems and do it in such a way that it remains grounded and controllable. We are not building an ill-defined and ethereal superintelligence; we are building a practical technology explicitly designed only to serve humanity.
¬†
Our recent work demonstrates the value of this narrower form of domain specific superintelligence. The New England Journal of Medicine includes a Case Challenge in every issue ‚Äì a list of symptoms and a patient to diagnose. It‚Äôs fiendishly difficult even for domain experts, let alone the average doctor. Our orchestrator, MAI-DxO, managed to reach 85% across the Case Challenges. Human doctors max out at about 20%, and need to order many more expensive tests. In our view both clinicians and patients alike would welcome the extra support.¬†This work just hints at the potential to revolutionize healthcare. (More here: https://lnkd.in/eSZ8m6T8)
¬†
Superintelligence could be the best invention ever ‚Äì but only if it puts the interests of humans above everything else. Only if it‚Äôs in service to humanity.¬†Ultimately what HSI requires is an industry shift in approach. Are those building AI optimizing for AI or for humanity, and who gets to judge?
¬†
At Microsoft AI, we believe humans matter more than AI. We want to build AI that deeply reflects our wider mission to empower every person on the planet.¬†¬†
¬†
Humanist, applied - this is the superintelligence I believe the world wants. It‚Äôs the superintelligence I want to build. And it‚Äôs what we‚Äôre going to build on MAI‚Äôs Superintelligence Team.
¬†
More on the MAI blog this morning: https://lnkd.in/edFGgg6K

author: Unknown
post_text:
What a privilege to be at AFROTECH this year, the largest tech conference for Black professionals, creators, and founders. Onstage with Jeff Nelson, we unpacked this strange, thrilling time we're in with AI. You have people at all extremes - AI is underwhelming, or the apocalypse, or utopia.

Two things can be true: AI development should accelerate. And we should be afraid of AI.

If you're not afraid of AI, you don't really understand it. The fear is healthy and the skepticism is necessary. We don't need unbridled accelerationism.

We need caution and care and guardrails, whilst at the same time knowing that this is going to change the world for the better and it does need to accelerate.

Because if we get it right, AI could unlock incredible abundance. Dramatically reduce the cost of living, invent new more effective drugs and treatments, improve education and opportunity for everyone.

These are not contradictions. The risk and reward go hand in hand. Finding our way forward means acknowledging both. Means ensuring human interests come first, always. Means even as we innovate, defining what we WON'T do.

Leaving the conference so inspired, so energized - lots more writings and brain dumps to come. 

In the meantime, thank you to AfroTech for having me, Jeff for one of the best conversations I've had all year, and every single person I got to meet. It really reminded me why I do what I do.

post_text:
Just wrapped our earnings call and wanted to share a few highlights from the quarter. 

Bottom line: We‚Äôve got great momentum across our AI platform and our family of Copilots,¬†fueling our increasing investments in both capital and talent.

We‚Äôre building a planet-scale cloud and AI factory.

We‚Äôll increase our AI capacity by 80% this year, and nearly double our DC footprint over the next two.

That includes Fairwater in Wisconsin, the world‚Äôs most powerful AI datacenter, which will scale to two gigawatts alone.

We are building a fungible fleet that spans every stage of the AI lifecycle and is constantly optimized to deliver the best ROI and TCO for us and our customers.

One example: during the quarter, we increased the token throughput for GPT-4.1 and GPT-5 by more than 30% per GPU.

Our family of Copilots and agents also surpassed over 150 million monthly active users across high value domains:

‚Ä¢ Information work: 90 percent of the F500 now use Microsoft 365 Copilot ‚Äì and we‚Äôre shipping updates very fast
‚Ä¢ Coding: GitHub Copilot now has 26 million-plus users
‚Ä¢ Security: 36+ agents integrated across Entra, Defender, Purview, Intune
‚Ä¢ Science & Health: We helped document 17 million-plus patient encounters, up 5X year over year
‚Ä¢ Consumer: Tons of new capabilities announced over the past two weeks, from Groups and Mico in Copilot, to "Hey Copilot" in Windows

And this week, we signed a new agreement with OpenAI, a milestone for both companies. 

It‚Äôs been an incredible investment, with nearly 10X return and no carry. All the value goes straight to shareholders.

Another thing I feel super proud about is that Microsoft is now behind two of the largest nonprofits in the world!

You can read more about our results here: https://lnkd.in/gxtVeMk2

Get things done with Copilot Actions: With your permission, Edge can book dinner, buy concert tickets, or shop for gifts - just say what you need by voice or chat. It handles the steps for you, even across multiple tabs. (Limited preview, US)

author: Unknown
post_text:
All of today's Copilot announcements boil down to one core idea: we're betting on humanist AI. An AI that always puts humans first.
¬†
AI that's social instead of isolating.
¬†
AI that helps you connect with your real-world relationships, instead of roleplaying romance.
¬†
AI that supports to show up in the real world, instead of pulling you away from it.
¬†
AI that helps bring out the best in us, not the worst.
¬†
Because AI should work for humans. Never the other way around.
¬†
Lots more hot takes and product updates at our Copilot Sessions event this morning, but a few highlights:
¬†
Copilot Groups: Invite up to 32 friends, classmates, or teammates to a shared conversation and brainstorm, co-write, plan, or study together. Copilot will keep everyone on the same page by summarizing threads, proposing options, tallying votes, and splitting tasks.
¬†
Mico: A super expressive, customizable visual character - one that can listen, react, and even change colors if you opt in. And there may or may not be a pretty fun easter egg the team built in‚Ä¶
¬†
Copilot Mode in Edge: An AI browser built the way your brain actually works, combining Voice, Vision, and Actions for a next-level, seamless browsing experience. We're also introducing Journeys, which organizes your history by topic and intent instead of timestamp, making it easy to jump back in and keep going.
¬†
Plus so much more that won't fit in a single LinkedIn post - from health to tutoring to personality updates.
¬†
You can check out the full event streaming now: https://lnkd.in/gWw2d6RY
¬†
And there's even more detail on the blog for those who like a deep dive: https://lnkd.in/g8YasNuG
¬†
Everything is live now in the US and rolling out fast beyond over the next few weeks. So please, jump in, try them out, and give us feedback! Building for people starts with hearing from you. Keep it coming.

post_text:
Spam, malware, phishing emails ‚Äî it can be difficult to stay safe online. In her role as a Product Manager on the User Protection team in Brazil, Googler Rebeca‚Äôs job is to ensure people‚Äôs safety when using our products. ‚ÄúMy focus is on solving common abuse types in Google products, at scale,‚Äù she explains. "My core work involves partnering with the teams behind Google products like Maps, Blogger, and Messages. I focus on two key areas: driving adoption, to ensure as many products as possible are protected by our safety platform, and expanding coverage, to make sure we can solve for the most common types of abuse they face."

This type of work requires constant strategic adjustment. "Adaptability is crucial,‚Äù Rebeca shares. ‚ÄúThe scale at Google means new data, new user trends, and new technologies emerge constantly. Being able to quickly learn and adjust your strategy is essential to keeping up and staying effective."

The power of her team's mission has also fueled her personal growth when it came to her fear of public speaking ‚Äî giving her the courage to speak at an internal conference. "Even though I had been working on it during my career, it was at Google that I had a turning point when I realized that the mission of our User Protection work, and the message that came with it, was bigger than my fear."

Rebeca‚Äôs advice for those interested in similar roles? "If you are passionate about building products, Google gives you the opportunity to apply your skills at an unimaginable scale. The work you do here can genuinely impact the daily experience of billions of users."

Explore open roles at Google Brazil ‚Üí https://goo.gle/49byhGG

Day-to-day, she manages centralized deliverables for the EMEA region, collaborating with both internal and external stakeholders. Her role involves leading the International Accounting and Reporting deliverables, governance, and escalations across EMEA, driving both project management and continuous process innovation.

‚ÄúGoogle operates on a fundamentally different and more dynamic level than other organizations I've worked with,‚Äù Tejal says. ‚ÄúIt is more than just a job; it is a space where ideas are limitless, continuous innovation is the norm, and work satisfaction is high due to the focus on efficiency and challenging the status quo every day. I've found satisfaction in challenging work that involves both innovation and efficiency. post_text:
When I‚Äôm asking friends, family, or a store associate for fashion ideas, I don‚Äôt just say: ‚Äúwork bag.‚Äù¬† Instead I say what I‚Äôm *really* after, like: ‚ÄúI‚Äôm looking for a black leather work bag that‚Äôs comfortable, fits my laptop, and is appropriate for customer meetings.‚Äù üíº

Now with AI, technology is finally catching up to how we actually shop!¬† At Google, we're leading this shift with AI that‚Äôs both conversational and agentic ‚Äì meaning you can say what you want and then it‚Äôll help you buy it: 

‚Üí Conversational: You can ask a shopping question in AI Mode (and follow up conversationally to refine), and get an AI-organized response that brings together rich visuals and all the details you need (like price, reviews, and inventory info). 

And we‚Äôre also bringing new shopping features to the Gemini app!

Put another way, welcome to the era of "vibe shopping" :)

‚Üí Agentic: Our agentic AI can call nearby businesses to check on products (like if the store has what you‚Äôre looking for in-stock) and promotions.¬† 

And with agentic checkout, Google can track an item‚Äôs price and when the price drops for eligible merchants, you can give Google permission to complete the purchase for you. 

These updates are designed to support a thriving ecommerce ecosystem.¬† Shoppers get to delegate the tedious parts of online shopping (but keep the fun and control!), and merchants can capture high-intent sales that might have otherwise been abandoned. 

It‚Äôs pretty awesome to see advancements like these even change my own shopping behavior.¬† This is the bag I ended up getting‚Ä¶ with a very cute model, our cat Paris :) 

Great insights on Google‚Äôs shopping AI transformation from The Verge: https://lnkd.in/gxCKcGDQ

Today, we published a paper, ‚ÄúAI and the Future of Learning,‚Äù outlining Google‚Äôs approach to building AI to help improve learning outcomes for everyone. Here are 5 takeaways:

1) AI has the potential to reduce barriers to education and unlock human potential.¬†
2) This transformation hinges on paying attention to how people learn ‚Äî the science of learning.
3) That‚Äôs why Google‚Äôs tools for learning are grounded in best-in-class learning science, and the AI models that power them are rooted in pedagogical principles.
4) Realizing the promise of AI in education demands collaborative efforts among technology companies, educators, policymakers, and learners.¬†
5) To navigate challenges like academic integrity, we must equip educators and students with the AI literacy needed to use these tools most beneficially.

author: Unknown
post_text: This week at Google, we announced a major breakthrough in quantum computing. Here are three things to know.

author: Unknown
post_text:
Over the past two weeks, we've seen a flurry of new results from Google Research, from genomics to quantum computing to geospatial understanding.

These breakthroughs exemplify what I call the ‚Äúmagic cycle‚Äù of research: addressing global challenges and opportunities with foundational research that leads directly to real-world applications and solutions. These solutions not only benefit millions around the world, but they also uncover more important problems to solve.

Research is our chance‚Äîand imperative‚Äîto improve day-to-day lives, and address societal challenges and opportunities, and it means that research and innovation is never 'done.' 

Three highlights on latest from Google Research in collaboration with other teams:

‚ú® Fighting Cancer with AI¬†
Our decade-long effort in genomics led to DeepSomatic, an AI-powered tool that accurately spots genetic variants in cancer cells. Our partners used it to identify 10 new genetic variants in childhood leukemia samples that were missed by previous techniques, advancing personalized treatment. Separately, the Cell2Sentence-Scale 27B model successfully generated a novel, validated hypothesis for a combination cancer therapy.

‚ú® Verifiable Quantum Advantage¬†
We demonstrated the Quantum Echoes algorithm on our Willow chip. This marks the world's first verifiable quantum algorithm that brings us a step closer to practical applications of quantum computing, such as designing better materials and medicines, by more precisely modeling quantum behavior that classical supercomputers cannot.

‚ú® Understanding Earth¬†
Our new initiative, Earth AI, focuses on synthesizing disparate geospatial information and predictive models. This multi-year effort will make it possible to tackle complex planetary science and crisis resilience questions‚Äîlike precisely predicting vulnerable communities and infrastructure during an impending storm, or help in complex logistics planning‚Äîthat are currently impossible to answer due to the complexity of integrating diverse data.

The magic cycle is accelerating significantly, powered by stronger models, and agentic tools, like AI co-scientist and AI-based expert-level empirical software. And it applies across many disciplines and domains.

Today, the energy was palpable at our flagship Research@ event in Mountain View. The opportunity to advance research and AI is greater than ever and I‚Äôm excited about how AI can be an amplifier of human ingenuity.

Energized by the amazing team of Google Research and what they can do in collaboration with great colleagues and the community.

Read more in my blog: https://lnkd.in/d778XcWm

author: Unknown
post_text:
Today, we‚Äôve published a new breakthrough quantum algorithm in Nature Magazine, that provides a path towards real-world quantum computing applications.

The Google Quantum AI team has successfully run an algorithm that can compute the structure of a molecule, with potential for real-world applications.

Our Willow quantum processor ran the algorithm ‚Äî which we‚Äôve named ‚ÄúQuantum Echoes‚Äù ‚Äî 13,000x faster than the best classical algorithm on one of the world‚Äôs fastest supercomputers. 

Importantly this computation is verifiable, which means its outcome can be repeated by other quantum computers or confirmed by experiments.

This is the first time in history that any quantum computer has successfully run a verifiable algorithm that surpasses the ability of classical computers. With our latest breakthrough algorithm on Willow, we‚Äôre optimistic that within five years we‚Äôll see real-world applications that are possible only on quantum computers.

Read more here: https://lnkd.in/eQ8PsFsh

author: Unknown
post_text:
One of the most significant opportunities for AI to benefit society is helping to accelerate cancer research and early diagnosis.

Just this week¬†our teams, working with partners, shared advances on three fronts:

Research breakthroughs: Our C2S-Scale 27B foundation model, built with Yale University and based on Gemma, is a new frontier for single-cell analysis. The tool allows researchers to quickly simulate cell responses to thousands of potential treatments, speeding up the search for new medicines. https://lnkd.in/efr4KnPX

Targeted Treatments: We're open-sourcing DeepSomatic, our new model capable of accurately differentiating actual genetic cancer variants from the technical artifacts (or errors) introduced during sequencing, addressing a critical hurdle in developing treatments. DeepSomatic successfully found hard-to-find small variants in pediatric leukemia cells that were missed by other tools. https://lnkd.in/evxkBGup

Access to screenings: Color Health, supported by Google.org funding, is launching the Color Assistant to help 20,000 women access breast cancer risk assessments and screening. Powered by Gemini 2.5 models and Vertex AI, the agent quickly determines eligibility for mammograms, schedules breast cancer screenings, and coordinates follow up. 

Excited about these developments, and look forward to further progress.

post_text:
It was great to be in West Memphis to announce that Google is investing $4B in Arkansas to support the next wave of American innovation powered by AI. Google‚Äôs work in Arkansas will deliver energy capacity and create high-paying jobs, while protecting energy affordability for ratepayers. This commitment includes accelerating energy affordability initiatives in the local community through an Energy Impact Fund, working in partnership with Entergy to cover the full cost of powering the data center in West Memphis to keep rates down, and also deploying load flexibility solutions to lower data center energy demand during peak grid periods. Google‚Äôs investment will also help ensure that Arkansans can gain AI fluency and job-ready skills, training the next generation of great talent that will build and benefit from the opportunities technology presents ‚Äì with a wonderful role model in my extraordinary colleague John Jumper, 2024 Nobel Prize winner in Chemistry for his work with Google DeepMind and a proud son of Arkansas.

Thank you to Gov. Sarah Sanders and Mayor Marco McClendon for the support and partnership.

For Sarita, an AI Specialist on Google Cloud‚Äôs Healthcare and Life Sciences Customer Engineering team, her role is all about being a trusted advisor and translator.

‚ÄúMy day-to-day work involves designing and implementing agentic AI workflows to unlock new efficiencies, evangelizing the Google Cloud Vertex AI and Agentic platform, collaborating across different teams like Product and Engineering to create production-ready solutions and helping to scale and upskill other teams,‚Äù she explains. 

Sarita partners directly with customers, including executives and VPs, to find solutions that will create new business opportunities and build deep trust. "The most challenging ‚Äî and also the most rewarding ‚Äî aspect of my role is bridging the gap between the speed of AI innovation and the nature of the healthcare industry," Sarita says. "The challenge lies in translating the 'art of the possible' with this new technology into practical, reliable and secure solutions."

Beyond her technical work, Sarita is a dedicated mentor, coaching women in tech, new hires and early-career professionals. ‚ÄúWhat I find most fulfilling is acting as a powerful advocate for career growth and belonging. Seeing others succeed and grow is the most rewarding part of this journey,‚Äù she shares.

Sarita‚Äôs advice for anyone on a similar career path is to build a strong internal network. "Don't just put your head down and focus on your individual tasks,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúBe relentlessly curious about what other teams are working on. The biggest challenges are rarely solved alone, and your ability to find and collaborate with the right people is the fastest way to accelerate your learning and your impact."

post_text:
The White House just launched the Genesis Mission‚Äîa national effort to accelerate scientific discovery using AI. It‚Äôs a major step toward giving American scientists the data, compute, and tools they need to innovate faster.

The Genesis Mission recognizes what we‚Äôve seen firsthand in our partnerships with Argonne, Lawrence Livermore, Los Alamos, Oak Ridge, and others. When America‚Äôs world-class datasets, secure research infrastructure, and frontier AI come together, the U.S. can lead in energy, biotech, advanced manufacturing, semiconductors, and critical materials. Read more about the Genesis Mission: https://lnkd.in/gZuaFP3H

We‚Äôre already seeing early examples of AI accelerating science. With GPT-5, mathematicians, physicists, and biologists are making faster progress on real problems and saving weeks or months. 

AI is the next great scientific instrument, helping experts explore more ideas, test more directions, and uncover connections that had been hidden for decades.

The public sees the need. 60% of Americans worry breakthroughs take too long to reach them. 73% say we need new tools to accelerate discovery, and 69% see U.S. leadership in science as a top national priority. Faster discovery affects health, materials, and security.

I'm excited to see the U.S. move boldly here, and we‚Äôre committed to contributing through OpenAI for Science, helping scientists across the country push the frontier of knowledge further and faster. Read more here: https://lnkd.in/g5RATC4A.

We‚Äôll be talking more about this in an upcoming Forum session with @bkspears9 of Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, diving into how AI and America‚Äôs national labs can work together to make scientific discovery faster. Details: https://lnkd.in/gpmgdV-h

post_text:
We‚Äôre releasing new research on how GPT-5 is accelerating scientific discovery.

In collaboration with researchers at universities and national laboratories, the paper brings together early experiments offering the first signs of how GPT-5 can strengthen research across mathematics, physics, biology, computer science, astronomy, and materials science.

The case studies highlight where GPT-5 can contribute today‚Äîsynthesizing scattered results, surfacing mechanisms, navigating literature conceptually, accelerating tough computations, and even helping generate new proofs of unsolved propositions.

These are early signals with well-defined limits. But the direction is encouraging: faster exploration, stronger workflows, and a path toward deeper, reliable AI-assisted discovery as capabilities improve.

Today‚Äôs paper, ‚ÄúEarly science acceleration experiments with GPT-5,‚Äù offers a clear, grounded view of what models like GPT-5 can and cannot do in real research settings.

post_text:
We‚Äôve developed a new way to train small AI models with internal mechanisms that are easier for humans to examine and understand.

Language models like the ones behind ChatGPT have complex, sometimes surprising internal structures, and we don‚Äôt yet fully understand how they work. 

This approach is an early step toward closing that gap, and a part of a broader set of efforts across OpenAI to make our systems more interpretable‚Äîdeveloping methods that help us understand why a model produced a given output. In some cases that means looking at the model‚Äôs step-by-step reasoning, and in others it means trying to reverse-engineer the small circuits inside the network. 

There‚Äôs still a long path to fully understanding the complex behaviors of our most capable models.

https://lnkd.in/gqWJyw_b

post_text:
Every year, hundreds of thousands of U.S. servicemembers transition from military to civilian life with a long list of things to figure out: job hunting, evaluating education options, navigating earned benefits, housing, finances, and getting used to a new routine. Nearly half of post-9/11 veterans say their adjustment to civilian life was difficult.

Today we‚Äôre announcing that U.S. servicemembers and veterans can receive a free year of ChatGPT Plus if they‚Äôre within 12 months of retirement or separation. This initiative originated with veterans working at OpenAI who use these tools every day. They know firsthand how ChatGPT can help with the next chapter, from building resumes to exploring new careers. 

U.S. servicemembers and veterans who are interested can learn more at‚Å† chatgpt.com/veterans-claim.

They will get access to our latest models and features, 100 example chats‚Å† for veterans (written by OpenAI veterans), and a customized getting started video‚Å†tailored to veterans and hosted on the OpenAI Academy. And we‚Äôre doing this alongside SheerID‚Äîleveraging their permission-based verification platform to make sure the access goes to those who‚Äôve served and are transitioning to their next stage of life.

author: Unknown
post_text:
Today, OpenAI is announcing that U.S. servicemembers and veterans can receive a free year of ChatGPT Plus if they‚Äôre within 12 months of retirement or separation. This effort was driven by veterans at OpenAI,¬† including me, who‚Äôve seen firsthand how these tools can make the transition to civilian life a little easier.

I‚Äôm an AI Adoption Manager at OpenAI and a 20-year US Army veteran. When I left the military, I didn‚Äôt have a traditional tech background. I relied on ChatGPT early on to bridge the gap, learning cloud concepts, translating technical jargon, and gaining the confidence to navigate a new career path. Over time, I went from user to power user to someone helping public-sector teams understand how to think with AI.

That journey ultimately brought me to OpenAI, where I work every day to help governments and public servants use frontier AI responsibly and effectively.

If AI helped me build a new career, I know it can help others do the same. Proud to have helped bring this initiative to life ‚Äî and excited for what it can unlock for those who‚Äôve served. 

Offer page: https://lnkd.in/gvQtqaxc

There is a link in the comments to a video walkthrough I made for the OpenAI Academy on best practices for using ChatGPT for military transitions.

We‚Äôre introducing IndQA ‚Äî a benchmark for evaluating AI systems on Indian culture and languages.

IndQA measures knowledge and reasoning across everyday Indian life ‚Äî spanning 2,278 questions, 12 languages, and 10 cultural domains, created in partnership with 261 domain experts across India. Unlike existing benchmarks, IndQA is designed to probe culturally nuanced, reasoning-heavy tasks that existing evaluations struggle to capture.

This reflects our commitment to making AI more useful and accessible globally, and we hope IndQA informs and inspires further benchmark work in the research community.

author: Unknown
post_text:
üß† ü§ù

Prompt 1: Critical Thinking
Here‚Äôs my idea/plan: [insert].
Act as a critical thinker ‚Äî question my assumptions, challenge the logic, and highlight any blind spots I might be missing. Stress test my reasoning and point out weaknesses, but don‚Äôt rewrite or change the original idea itself.

Prompt 2: Reframe Through a Different Lens
Here‚Äôs the core idea: [insert].
Reframe it from different angles ‚Äî for example, shift to a new audience POV, explore an emotional trigger, or create a different positioning strategy.
Show me fresh perspectives I might not have considered, while keeping the main essence intact.

Prompt 3: Structure My Messy Ideas
Here‚Äôs a messy brain dump: [insert].
Turn it into a clear outline or practical framework that keeps my natural voice and style intact. Don‚Äôt add new ideas ‚Äî instead, focus on bringing clarity and structure so my notes flow logically and can be used to take action immediately.

Prompt 4: Spot Hidden Assumptions
Here‚Äôs my plan: [insert].
Identify the hidden assumptions I might be making ‚Äî especially the ones that are risky, flawed, or could simply be wrong. Help me see where I may be overconfident, what I‚Äôm taking for granted, and what could undermine my plan if left unchecked.

Prompt 5: Stress-Test With Scenarios
Here‚Äôs my strategy: [insert].
Show me 3 best-case scenarios, 3 worst-case scenarios, and 3 likely scenarios.
Explain how each outcome could realistically unfold, and what that would mean for the success or failure of my overall strategy.

Prompt 6: Play Devil‚Äôs Advocate
Here‚Äôs my plan: [insert].
Argue against it as if you completely disagree. Be blunt, direct, and brutally honest. Tell me what the critics would say, where they‚Äôd find the weak spots, and why my plan might not work at all.

üìπ: Jessica Camilleri-Shelton

author: Unknown
post_text:
OpenAI, calm down. I can only type so fast. Let‚Äôs cover the new releases and why they matter:

Since last Thursday,¬†OpenAI has launched ChatGPT Pulse, Commerce in chat, parental controls, and Sora 2 + Sora app.

Here‚Äôs the full rundown:

‚Üí ChatGPT Pulse (preview): Pro users on mobile can now get a daily, proactive research cards based on your chats, feedback, and optional calendar. You can thumbs-up/down and curate what shows next. Why does this matter? AI is getting more proactive! You won‚Äôt have to prompt all the dang time!

‚Üí Commerce in chat: OpenAI rolled out Instant Checkout using the open Agentic Commerce Protocol (built with Stripe). You can already buy from U.S. Etsy sellers inside ChatGPT, with Shopify merchants ‚Äúcoming soon.‚Äù Why does this matter? ChatGPT was already being used to shop and browse, now it‚Äôs going fully vertical. More ‚Äúcomplete‚Äù experiences will happen inside ChatGPT.

‚Üí Parental controls: New teen safety features now let parents link accounts, set limits, and dial down sensitive content. It‚Äôs imperfect (and will evolve), but this seems to be the most concrete teen-focused guardrail set we‚Äôve seen from them to date. Why does this matter? AI is becoming more integrated into our personal lives and full families are signing up for it as an app they use together, this was the obvious next step.

‚Üí Sora 2 + Sora app: A major step-up in physical realism and control, now with synced dialogue/SFX, plus a new (currently) invite-only iOS app that looks and feels like TikTok, but for AI-generated video only. Cameos let friends appear with consent and revocable control. Available in US/Canada first. Why does this matter? Meta and TikTok own a huge part of the commerce chain because of a social-first strategy, OpenAI wants a piece of the pie.

Overall: more proactive and personalized systems, more vertical integration, more connections with family and friends, and more weirdness still to come.

What say you on these releases?

Stay tuned for more. Dev Day is in less than a week üëÄ

author: Unknown
post_text:
This morning, the OpenAI Economic Research team and our co-author Professor David Deming (Harvard University) released a first-of-its-kind research paper on how ChatGPT is being used across the world. This is very exciting for me personally because one of the reasons I joined OpenAI was to produce research on how AI is changing our economy and society.

The paper is officially a National Bureau of Economic Research working paper (https://lnkd.in/gPDB3fuq) which means it will contribute to the conversation among leading economists as well as the broader discussion of AI in the media. 

I‚Äôll be sharing takeaways from the paper on an ongoing basis. One early finding: our user base has shifted over time to better reflect the broader population. For example, just after ChatGPT launched, about 80% of users had typically masculine names. Today, that share is closer to 50%.

Read more about the paper here:¬†https://lnkd.in/gdZ_cyug

Special thanks to Carl, Christopher, Kevin, Tom, and Zo√´ for leading this effort.

post_text: Whenever I talk with people about AI, one of the first questions I get is almost always: what will this mean for my job? I believe AI will open up more opportunities than any technology in history ‚Äì but it will also change how work gets done. Today we‚Äôre announcing OpenAI-Certified and the OpenAI Jobs Platform ‚Äì two new initiatives that are about helping people become fluent in AI and connecting them with employers who need their skills. We can‚Äôt eliminate the disruption AI will bring, but we can make sure the benefits are shared broadly, not just by a fortunate few. This is one big step in the right direction.

As OpenAI's Chief Economist, I get lots of questions about how AI is changing jobs. To help answer them, I‚Äôve been speaking with people across occupations to learn how they‚Äôre thinking about AI and how it‚Äôs showing up in their day to day. I wanted to start with some professions that you are not reading about every day in the news if you are tracking the AI & jobs discussion in the press.¬†
Over the next few weeks, I‚Äôll be sharing highlights from these conversations paired with my takeaways on how AI is shaping the future of work. 

First up is my conversation with Ashley Moore, better known as Principal Mo, an elementary and middle school principal who was a very early user of ChatGPT. 

A champion of AI in education, she has helped fellow administrators, teachers, and students in her school learn how to integrate ChatGPT in impactful ways. Hear her view on the potential of AI in education and where it fits into the history of digital transformation in the classroom.

author: Unknown
post_text:
One of the things I‚Äôm most excited about with ChatGPT is how it‚Äôs revolutionizing healthcare. GPT-5 is our best model yet for answering health questions. It scores significantly higher than any previous model on HealthBench, an evaluation OpenAI published earlier this year based on realistic scenarios in partnership with over 250 physicians. 
Felipe, a member of our OpenAI team, and his wife Carolina shared their story on today‚Äôs livestream, and it really moved me. Last October, Carolina was hit with three cancer diagnoses in one week. Like many, her biopsy results felt overwhelming and confusing. On a whim, she took a screenshot of the biopsy report and put it into ChatGPT. Within seconds, it translated the medical jargon into plain language, helping her feel more in control and more prepared to talk to her doctor about next steps. She‚Äôs kept using ChatGPT throughout her cancer journey, even to help make a tough choice about radiation when doctors gave conflicting advice. It‚Äôs incredible to hear how ChatGPT restored her sense of agency during these critical decisions. You can watch the full livestream and their story here:

author: Unknown
post_text:
In front of an online audience of thousands last Thursday, OpenAI‚Äôs head recruiter, Joaquin Qui√±onero Candela, described one of the common threads that draws talent to the company: OpenAI‚Äôs culture. 

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre a culture of doers who do things ‚Äì with autonomy, with agency,‚Äù he said at the OpenAI Forum. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs no sitting around asking for permission.‚Äù 

Joaquin also mentioned how OpenAI‚Äôs mission is attractive to candidates. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre building AGI, and we‚Äôre bringing it to humanity in a way that‚Äôs responsible and beneficial.‚Äù And he explained how it‚Äôs the people at OpenAI who draw talent to the company. ‚ÄúWe often say good people draw good people. And people want to work with like-minded people ‚Ä¶ people who, you know, want to jump into the deep-end and into the unknown.‚Äù 

Joaquin‚Äôs comments came during an hourlong conversation at the OpenForum titled: ‚ÄúCareers at the Frontier: Hiring the Future at OpenAI,‚Äù where he discussed his own career trajectory ‚Äì stints at Facebook and LinkedIn before coming to OpenAI to work on AI safety and even a three-month turn as an intern on the company‚Äôs health team. 

Joaquin‚Äôs current role at OpenAI is Head of Recruiting, and he explained why he made the move to the post. ‚ÄúAlthough OpenAI is about 10 years old, in many ways we‚Äôre only getting started now. I feel like we‚Äôre at the beginning of building a company that is probably going to be generational,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúIt became a no-brainer.‚Äù¬† 

When Natalie Cone, who was moderating the conversation as head of the OpenAI Forum Community, asked him what a typical day looks like for his recruiting team, Joaquin replied, ‚ÄúOh, a typical day is crazy.‚Äù He explained: ‚ÄúWe have a constantly changing environment. The goals are always changing. We can‚Äôt really predict what products would be shipping long term, because the models keep getting more capable. It‚Äôs very hard, then, to know how much do different teams need to grow.‚Äù 

Approximately 11,000 guests registered for this online discussion ‚Äì more than any other previous OpenAI Forum event.

author: Unknown
post_text:
I will officially start at OpenAI as CEO of Applications on August 18. I am sharing this essay on why I believe AI can be the greatest source of empowerment for all. https://lnkd.in/gfrq627N 

I‚Äôve always considered myself a pragmatic technologist ‚Äî someone who loves technology not for its own sake, but for the direct impact it can have on people‚Äôs lives. That‚Äôs what makes this job so exciting, since I believe AI will unlock more opportunities for more people than any other technology in history. If we get this right, AI can give everyone more power than ever.

But I also realize those opportunities won‚Äôt magically appear on their own.

Every major technology shift can expand access to power ‚Äì the power to make better decisions, shape the world around us, and control our own destiny in new ways. But it can also further concentrate wealth and power in the hands of a few ‚Äî usually people who already have money, credentials, and connections.

That‚Äôs why we have to be intentional about how we build and share these technologies so they lead to greater opportunity and prosperity for more people. The choices we make today will shape whether the coming transformation leads to greater empowerment for all, or greater concentration of wealth and power for the few.

We can start by making sure the keys to empowerment and opportunity ‚Äî knowledge, health, creative expression, economic freedom, time, and support ‚Äî are widely available. You can read more in the link I shared about the potential AI has to transform each of these aspects of people‚Äôs lives.

If we can make intelligence accessible everywhere, affordable to everyone, and easy to understand, we can drive the biggest opportunity engine the world has ever seen and help more people live better lives. I‚Äôm looking forward to building this future alongside my brilliant new colleagues at OpenAI, and I‚Äôll have a lot more to share soon.

post_text:
A look inside our first university #AIatMetaHackathon ü§©

We welcomed 50 software engineering students to Meta HQ for three days of hands-on AI innovation, collaboration, and learning. Hackathons are a huge part of Meta culture, and there‚Äôs no better way to highlight AI at Meta than by inviting students to engage live with our technology firsthand.

Event highlights:
üíª Immersive VR projects on Meta Quest 3 using Llama, text-to-speech, and ImageGen
üé§ Insights from Mat Velloso, VP of Product Management, on Meta‚Äôs vision for AI
üßë‚Äçüíº Mentorship from Kirk Barker, Product Manager, Reality Labs
üëì Tested the latest Meta AI smart glasses and neural band technology
üéÆ Late-night coding, arcade games, and camaraderie in the #HackerDen

Across 11 teams, students brought a range of creative ideas to life from applications supporting health and well-being to tools that enhance everyday experiences with AI. Congrats to our winners:

üèÜStage Buddy: Quest app to help users overcome fear of public speaking by simulating a realistic stage environment and virtual audience, while AI provides feedback on tone, pacing, volume, and stability.

üèÜMeta CompARe: Uses Quest and Llama to provide shoppers with prices, alternatives, and purchase options for any product, eliminating manual search.

üèÜLocus: Quest tool that enables movie & TV creators to virtually explore real-world locations, instantly generating camera-ready shot ideas and shareable storyboards, saving time and money on traditional location scouting.

It was inspiring to witness how today‚Äôs students are already building the future of AI technologies in just one weekend. We‚Äôre excited to see how their creativity and drive will continue to pave the way for advancements in AI throughout their careers! Learn more about future opportunities for students and grads here: https://lnkd.in/dC8xmrcG 

¬†#MetaCareers #LifeatMeta #AIatMeta

post_text:
‚ÄúGrowth is inevitable, especially for AI. So given that we know we‚Äôre going to grow our AI footprint at Meta, how can we ensure the environmental impacts are minimal? My team contributes to multiple projects ‚Äî from mineral extraction to software efficiency ‚Äî to ensure we‚Äôre reducing our carbon footprint across the full AI value chain.‚Äù ‚Äì Lisa Rivalin, Ph.D., Lead Engineer for Hardware Sustainability, AI Fleet and Hardware Lifecycle

The Open Compute Project (OCP) has come a long way since Meta helped launch it in 2011. What began as an initiative to open source custom Meta technology designs and improve global data center efficiency has grown into a vibrant community rethinking how hardware should be built to meet growing compute demands.

For Lisa Rivalin and Dharmesh Jani (DJ), the opportunity to contribute to OCP and shape technology used across the industry was a major reason why they joined Meta.

üéß Tune in to episode 80 of the Meta Tech Podcast to learn how Lisa, DJ and their team are using OCP to advance AI sustainability and push the boundaries of hardware innovation: https://lnkd.in/gZff_MAy

post_text:
üíª Embracing AI-enabled coding interviews at Meta! 

We are excited to announce we are piloting a new, AI-enabled software engineer coding interview to reflect the evolving role of software engineers and how the job is changing. As a tech company, our engineers use AI coding assistants in their day-to-day work to solve complex, real-world problems, so it‚Äôs important that our interviews reflect our current and evolving working environment.

ü§î What does this mean for candidates?¬†
If you‚Äôre part of the pilot group, you are encouraged to leverage authorized AI tools during your coding interview. It‚Äôs not ‚Äúcheating,‚Äù it‚Äôs how the job is evolving. This approach allows you to brainstorm, iterate and solve problems in a way that‚Äôs closer to real-world engineering at Meta. 

Hear from our engineers working on this pilot üëá
"I'm super excited for the AI-enabled coding interview; this new format enables engineers to actually execute their code, dive deeper into real practical problems, and lets candidates leverage AI to brainstorm and iterate." - Peter C., Software Engineer, Threads Product Team

‚ÄúAI has fundamentally changed the way software is developed, bringing more challenging tasks within reach of each engineer. Meta‚Äôs AI-first vision requires that we leverage the unbridled power of the AI-assisted engineering mind, which we would like to witness in our coding interview. Our modernized AI-enabled coding interview is a better representation of our work and of our mission as we build into the bold future.¬† - Nicholas O., Software Engineer, Programming Languages and Runtimes Team

At Meta, we are always evolving and adopting new technologies to empower our teams. We apply this same mentality to our recruiting experience, and we want to equip you with the tools you need to succeed while interviewing with us!

üîó Learn more about our hiring process and what to expect with AI-enabled coding interviews here: https://lnkd.in/gvjhJbkK

author: Unknown
post_text:
Proud to share Meta‚Äôs latest network infrastructure announcements from the 2025 OCP Global Summit!

At Meta, we believe that open hardware and collaborative innovation are key to building the next generation of AI-ready data centers. This year, our team has announced:

‚û°Ô∏è The evolution of our Disaggregated Scheduled Fabric (DSF), now supporting building-scale, non-blocking fabrics for large AI clusters.
‚û°Ô∏è  Our new Non-Scheduled Fabric (NSF) architecture, leveraging shallow-buffer 51T Ethernet switches to drive lower latency and higher performance for our largest gigawatt-scale clusters.
‚û°Ô∏è  The launch of Minipack3N, a 51.2 Tbps switch based on NVIDIA Spectrum-4, and new optics for 400G/800G interconnects.
‚û°Ô∏è  Meta‚Äôs role as a founding participant in the Ethernet for Scale-Up Networking (ESUN) initiative, working with industry leaders to advance open standards for AI networking.

For those at the show, we even gave a sneak peek of our next-generation, liquid-cooled rack full of network switches, aligned to the power density curve of future accelerators¬†- more on that coming‚Ä¶

These advances are the result of deep cross-team collaboration and a shared commitment to open, scalable, and efficient infrastructure. I‚Äôm grateful to work alongside so many talented engineers and partners ‚Äì both at Meta, and across the OCP community.

üëâ Read the full blog post:¬†https://lnkd.in/g-33_3CZ

If you‚Äôre passionate about open hardware, AI, and the future of networking, I invite you to join the conversation and help shape what comes next.
#OCP2025 #OpenCompute #AIInfrastructure #OpenHardware #Meta

post_text:
At #OCPSummit25, AMD showcased "Helios" ‚Äî our most advanced rack-scale AI reference system, built on Meta‚Äôs Open Rack for AI (ORW) design.

What does AMD "Helios" mean to our customers and partners?

‚úÖ Freedom to Build on Open Standards: 
With Meta‚Äôs Open Rack Wide (ORW) design at its core, "Helios" gives OEMs and ODMs a flexible, interoperable foundation to innovate without being locked into proprietary systems

‚úÖ Leadership Rack-Scale Performance:
Delivering breakthrough FP4 and FP8 performance for training and inference at scale with industry-leading 31 TB of HBM4 memory, powered by AMD Instinct MI400 GPUs, EPYC CPUs, Pensando DPUs, and other leading components

‚úÖ Scalable, High-Speed Connectivity:
Move data seamlessly across GPUs, nodes, and racks with massive scale-up and high throughput scale-out bandwidth ‚Äî keeping pace with AI at scale.

‚úÖ Operational Efficiency Built In:
Simplify deployment and servicing with double-wide layout and quick-disconnect liquid cooling that enhances sustainability and uptime.

‚úÖ Future-Ready by Design:
"Helios" provides a proven, OCP-aligned platform ready for the next generation of AI data centers.

Learn more about "Helios" and how AMD and Meta are advancing open AI infrastructure: https://lnkd.in/g45H53qM.

Mahima G., Rakesh R. and the rest of their Reality Labs team are hard at work trying to crack the code on 3D generation. Their biggest challenge? The lack of 3D training data.

‚ÄúThere just isn‚Äôt enough 3D data available to train our models on, so we have to be very creative in our problem-solving methods. We often leverage 2D data and extract whatever 3D-rich signals we can find to train our models. It‚Äôs a really interesting and open research problem.‚Äù ‚Äì Rakesh R., Director of AI Research

As Mahima and Rakesh work to solve this challenge, they‚Äôre also trying to realize a future where broadly accessible 3D generation and modeling capabilities will help more creators increase user engagement, accelerate feedback loops and streamline their time to market.

At Meta, our commitment to sustainability is about more than operating responsibly; it‚Äôs about having a positive impact on the world and supporting the communities we are part of. As we build the future of human connection, we strive to do so in ways that create a more sustainable world. üåç

Our 2025 Sustainability Report outlines some of the ways Meta is working to minimize the impact of our energy and water usage, support the decarbonization of our supply chain, and engage in partnerships to drive innovation.

Collaboration is key. We are working with partners across industries to scale solutions that accelerate sustainability and protect what matters most: the well-being of people and the planet.

Highlights include:
‚úîÔ∏è Matched 100% of electricity use with 15+ GW of clean and renewable energy.
‚úîÔ∏è Restored 1.6 billion gallons of water through 40+ projects.
‚úîÔ∏è Enabled 48% of suppliers to set science-based emissions targets.
‚úîÔ∏è Trained 60,000+ manufacturing workers on human rights and environmental standards.
‚úîÔ∏è Protected 4,000+ acres of native, biodiverse habitats.

üåü Applications for the Rotational Product Management (RPM) program are now open! üåü

ü§î What‚Äôs the RPM program?
The Rotational Product Management (RPM) program is an 18-month program designed for early career product managers. Participants will receive in-depth training, real-world experience and world-class mentorship while exploring various product groups within Meta.

We connected with RPM alumni to get the scoop on their experience. Here's what they had to sayüëá

‚úÖ¬† Why apply to the RPM program?
"The RPM program is your chance to cultivate core product skills, learn from seasoned product and tech leaders, and lead projects that have impact at scale. You'll be part of a supportive RPM community, inclusive of current and former RPMs." - Tiara G., Product Manager, Experiences PM Team

‚úÖ¬† What did you gain from the RPM program?
"This program let me stop choosing between passion and security. The rotational structure gave me the freedom to explore how my fascination with social dynamics could solve actual product challenges. It showed me how to turn what I was already passionate about into work that matters." - Salvador U. A., Product Manager, Reality Labs Trust

‚úÖ¬† How did RPM contribute to your growth?
"In my 3 years at Meta, I‚Äôve learned how to be a strong product manager who can adapt to any situation and work on a big variety of problems. Rotating between teams as an RPM teaches you to quickly ramp up, execute, and build meaningful relationships with internal and external partners."- Zarina T., Product Manager, Verticals Multi-Team

Who can apply? Whether you‚Äôre a recent graduate or looking for a career change by leveraging your technical or management skills, the RPM program can set you up for success. 

üëâ Learn more about the program here:¬†https://lnkd.in/g8R8tsdK 

üëâ Submit your application today:¬†https://lnkd.in/gyeEjTis 


#MetaCareers #MetaRPM #ProductManagers #LifeatMeta

author: Unknown
post_text:
Introducing DINOv3: a state-of-the-art computer vision model trained with self-supervised learning (SSL) that produces powerful, high-resolution image features. For the first time, a single frozen vision backbone outperforms specialized solutions on multiple long-standing dense prediction tasks.

Learn more here: https://lnkd.in/giU_-6_M

A few highlights of DINOv3:
1Ô∏è‚É£SSL enables 1.7B-image, 7B-param training without labels, supporting annotation-scarce scenarios including satellite imagery
2Ô∏è‚É£Produces excellent high-resolution features and state-of-the art performance on dense prediction tasks
3Ô∏è‚É£Versatile application across vision tasks and domains, all with a frozen backbone (no fine-tuning required)
4Ô∏è‚É£ Includes distilled smaller models (ViT-B, ViT-L) and ConvNeXt variants for deployment flexibility

To help foster innovation and collaboration in the computer vision community, we‚Äôre releasing DINOv3 under a commercial license with a full suite of pre-trained models, adapters, training and evaluation code, and (much!) more. Find them here: https://lnkd.in/gEptEtVR

Silent data corruptions (SDCs) pose a hidden challenge to AI model training and inference.

Meta‚Äôs AI teams implement innovative software-level defenses, such as gradient clipping and tri-variate computational training, to handle subtle hardware faults invisible at the silicon level. Combined with hardware telemetry and factory insights, these approaches ensure robustness as AI scales to unprecedented levels.

‚û°Ô∏è Learn more about our AI hardware reliability engineering: https://lnkd.in/gJDHZvgj

Jesse M., Lauren G. and Sean B. are research scientists on the EMG engineering and research team at Meta. Their goal? To reimagine the way we interact with technology by creating the world‚Äôs first generic human-computer neuromotor interface.

‚ÄúHistorically, generalization has been a significant challenge in the field of computer interfaces ‚Äî you can train the model to respond to a single person‚Äôs hand gestures, but the device often struggles to translate those learnings to new users. We want to develop a non-invasive strategy that can work for anyone.‚Äù ‚Äì Jesse M., Research Scientist

üéß Listen to episode 77 of the Meta Tech podcast to learn how these research scientists overcame these and other challenges using surface electromyography (sEMG) and machine learning: https://lnkd.in/graCANVz

post_text:
If you've known me for some time, you know that I like a good company survey. They can be a periscope, rising us up out of our echo chambers to tell us what people really think.
¬†
As the leader of Communications & Corporate Responsibility, I am particularly fond of the surveys that get at how people feel about the company broadly ‚Äì what we offer to consumers and businesses, but also our communities, the planet, partners (think SMBs) and our employees.
¬†
Last year, Forbes introduced a new survey called ‚ÄúForbes Most Trusted Companies in America‚Äù that analyzes 1,500 companies across multiple factors, including employee satisfaction, consumer trust, financial performance, and public sentiment. 

In last year‚Äôs list, we didn't rank so our team made sure that Forbes saw Amazon as both a tech and retail company (they previously only viewed us as a retailer), and that they knew about all the good things we were doing for customers, employees, and our communities. 
¬†
Forbes came out with the new 2026 yesterday, and I couldn‚Äôt be happier and more proud to report that Amazon ranked #2 on Forbes' Most Trusted Companies in America. This recognition is the result of the work our teams do every day to live the CCR Vision, ensuring that our customers‚Äô lives, communities, and the planet are better because of Amazon, and that people know about it.
¬†
Very grateful for all our teammates do every day to help the company earn this level of trust, which might be the most valuable asset we have as a company. Thank you for all that you do to help us earn and keep that trust. https://lnkd.in/e9Svw-tz

post_text:
Pretty much every Amazon project starts with a code name. Echo was ‚ÄúDoppler,‚Äù our first Kindle was ‚ÄúFiona,‚Äù and our EC2 network device project was ‚ÄúBlackfoot,‚Äù after the penguins our AWS team saw while doing the work in Cape Town.

For our satellite network, it was ‚ÄúProject Kuiper,‚Äù and today, we‚Äôre introducing the permanent name: Amazon Leo‚Äîfor the low Earth orbit (or LEO) constellation that powers the whole thing.

Team‚Äôs made lots of progress (150+ satellites up, >1 Gbps speeds, customers signing on) and am excited for the difference Leo will make for the ~500 million households, and millions of enterprises, orgs, and governments who need it. https://lnkd.in/g6QgJwFQ

post_text:
What if your biggest competitive advantage isn‚Äôt how technologically advanced you are... but how psychologically agile your teams are?

Today, we sit down with Matt Garman ‚Äî CEO of Amazon Web Services (AWS), a $120B business ‚Äî to dig into the leadership frameworks behind one of the world‚Äôs most innovative companies.

In this episode, you‚Äôll learn:

- How to use the ‚Äúone-way vs. two-way doors‚Äù framework to make faster, smarter decisions
- Why optimism (not na√Øvet√©) is a core competitive advantage for innovators
- The key to shipping a minimum lovable product customers actually want
- The real frictions in AI adoption‚Äîand why replacing juniors with AI backfires
- Why long-horizon energy bets (including nuclear) matter for innovation and sustainability

If you‚Äôre leading in a fast-moving world‚Äîor want to‚Äîthis conversation offers practical frameworks and a shot of grounded optimism to help your team move faster, smarter, and with more heart.

Take a listen‚Ä¶. Wherever you get your podcasts!

author: Unknown
post_text:
Love seeing this heartfelt note about our Delivery Service Partner, Ronald Dubon and team...
‚Äî
Sometimes, the smallest hearts remind the biggest companies what kindness truly looks like. When a four-year-old boy dreamed of having an Amazon-themed birthday party‚Äîcomplete with the thrill of seeing a real delivery van‚Äîno one could have imagined that Amazon itself would make that dream come true. Despite being one of the largest and busiest companies in the world, Amazon found the time, heart, and humanity to show up in a deeply personal way. 

On short notice, they didn‚Äôt just send one delivery van‚Äîthey brought two: a classic Amazon delivery van and a cutting-edge electric model. Their team arrived with smiles, good spirits, and arms full of gifts, turning a simple backyard celebration into a once-in-a-lifetime memory. Every child got to climb behind the wheel, honk the horn, and pretend to be an Amazon driver for a day. The laughter, joy, and awe on their faces said everything words could not.¬†
¬†
In a world where large corporations often feel distant, Amazon proved that compassion and community still matter. Their thoughtful gesture‚Äîdone not for publicity, but from genuine goodwill‚Äîbrought magic to a young boy‚Äôs birthday and touched every heart in attendance.
¬†
It was a powerful reminder that even the biggest companies are made up of people who care, and their unexpected generosity should never go unnoticed.¬†Thank you, Amazon, for showing that behind every box and logo lies a company capable of incredible kindness.

post_text:
As a long-time fan of the National Basketball Association (NBA), I couldn't be more excited to announce that AWS is now the Official Cloud AI Partner of the NBA! 

Our partnership will power "NBA Inside the Game powered by AWS," a breakthrough platform analyzing billions of data points that will change the way you watch and understand basketball. 

We're launching three stats: Defensive Box Score, which links defenders to specific plays, Shot Difficulty, analyzing every aspect beyond make/miss, and Gravity, with AI that tracks data 60 times per second! This stat quantifies how much a player warps the defense's normal positioning and behavior, even without touching the ball, something coaches have observed for years but couldn't previously measure. 

Basketball season is almost here (go Suns), and I can't wait to watch. https://lnkd.in/gePx8KbM

It's great to be back in New York. This week is particularly meaningful as I join world leaders and policymakers at the 80th United Nations General Assembly for critical discussions about the challenges and opportunities facing our global community. UNGA80 comes at a pivotal moment when technological innovation offers unprecedented potential to address some of humanity's most pressing issues.

I'll be engaging with global leaders on how we can collectively harness new technologies and innovate for impact while addressing concerns about development and governance. I'm particularly excited to share our vision for how we are developing and deploying responsible AI, and helping to expand internet connectivity through Amazon Project Kuiper to improve lives, create economic opportunity, and build a more sustainable future. post_text:
Take a tour through Amazon Web Services (AWS) Trainium's microchip metropolis:
üèôÔ∏è The Systolic Array: Our "downtown" where intensive calculations run around the clock, with billions of transistors packed into an area smaller than a postage stamp
üõ£Ô∏èThe Data Bus: Like city highways and transit systems, moving information at near light speed
üè† Memory Cells: Our "outer boroughs" - strategic storage spaces holding massive datasets for AI processing
‚ö° The Interposer: The underground infrastructure creating vital connections, just like a city's power lines and utilities
üåá The Greater Metropolitan Area: Where interconnected chips work in concert to form Ultra Servers, powering the next wave of generative AI

Learn how AWS chip architects think like city planners when designing and building the tiny devices that are helping to advance the development of gen AI. https://amzn.to/47svEQi

Our CEO Jensen Huang joined Y.L. Wang, TSMC vice president of operations, and Ray Chuang, CEO of TSMC Arizona, in Phoenix today to celebrate the first NVIDIA Blackwell wafer produced in the United States.

Onshoring world-class chipmaking to American soil is crucial to meeting the growing demand for AI.  

Within the next four years, NVIDIA plans to produce up to one-half-trillion dollars of AI infrastructure in the U.S. ‚Äî  collaborating with TSMC, Foxconn, Wistron, Amkor Technology, Inc., and SPIL ÁüΩÂìÅ.

post_text:
Torch: NYU's new supercomputer. 
With over 500 Nvidia H200 GPUs, Torch is the most powerful supercomputer in American academic institutions. 
Torch is a perfect name: not only the emblem of NYU is a torch, but the software that primarily runs on Torch is PyTorch. 
(Py)Torch is intimately linked with NYU. The original version of Torch was developed in the late 2000s / early 2010s by Ronan Collobert (at NEC at the time), Cl√©ment Farabet, and koray kavukcuoglu, who were PhD students in my lab. 
Torch later evolved into PyTorch under the leadership of Soumith Chintala who is also an NYU alum.

author: Unknown
post_text:
NEWS: IBM just dropped their quantum timeline.

I can't stop thinking about what I saw.

I spent the day at IBM's Technology in Action event in London exploring what enterprise AI and quantum computing look like in practice.

Here's what caught my attention:

1. Quantum Nighthawk processor (announced at the event):

‚Üí 30% more complex circuits than previous generations
‚Üí Each qubit connects to 4 others (vs 2-3 previously)
‚Üí Solves 30-40% larger problems on today's hardware
‚Üí Operations jump from 5,000 today to 100 million when fault-tolerant

The implications are massive:¬†
‚Ä¢ Moderna using quantum to explore medicine design
‚Ä¢ HSBC saw 34% increase in successful algorithmic trades
‚Ä¢ Problems classical computers can't touch become solvable

2. watsonx Orchestrate for AI agents:

‚Üí One system orchestrating multiple specialised agents
‚Üí Automatically routes to HR, IT, Legal agents based on query
‚Üí Pre-built integrations with ServiceNow, SAP, Salesforce
‚Üí Ferrari using it to generate real-time race insights for millions of fans

IBM's Client Zero strategy (drinking their own champagne):
‚Ä¢ $3B in productivity gains unlocked in 2024¬†
‚Ä¢ On track for $4.5B annually¬†
‚Ä¢ Tested across 70 business units and 270,000 employees

My takeaway:

I spoke with Adam Hammond (Business Leader for IBM Quantum EMEA) and Jessica Ridella (Global Technology Managing Director) this week.

Quantum advantage is the point at which quantum computers can solve problems that classical computers alone cannot handle effectively.

IBM expects quantum advantage by 2026 and fault-tolerant by 2029.

But what matters today:

66% of UK businesses are already seeing AI productivity gains, yet 62% admit they're barely scratching the surface.

The gap is now less about capability and more about deployment.

The models are ready. The infrastructure exists. The question is: are you?

#IBMPartner

Follow me Alex Banks for daily AI highlights and insights.
